awd_titl_txt: S&CC-IRG Track 1: Connecting the Smart-City Paradigm with a Sustainable Urban Infrastructure Systems Framework to Advance Equity in Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate a smart urban infrastructure systems framework for advancing access and wellbeing in cities.  With transformative new infrastructures (e.g., smart electricity grid, urban farms) on the horizon, this research will provide new perspectives on how the future spatial deployment of these new infrastructures in cities will shape wellbeing, health, and the environmental sustainability of outcomes in the different areas of cities.  The project advances basic research in multiple disciplines including environmental and civil engineering, computer science, urban planning and public policy.  It will create a unique public database, establish citizen science protocols, and advance the science of smart sustainable urban systems through knowledge co-production with cities engaged in infrastructure planning.  The project will engage in educational activities through interdisciplinary training for graduate students and professionals in urban planning, policy and sustainability.  Furthermore, a strong component of citizen science engagement is involved through K-12 teachers and students, particularly in schools with underrepresented populations.

Environmental sustainability, human health and wellbeing outcomes in cities are significantly shaped by key physical infrastructure provisions of water, energy, food, shelter, transportation-communications, sanitation waste management and public spaces, as well as their interactions with the social, environmental and urban form parameters.  The investigators will conduct an interdisciplinary, community-engaged research project in the cities of Minneapolis, St Paul, and Tallahassee.  The research will engage four themes: (a) Develop the first comprehensive fine-scale intra-urban database of over 100 social-ecological-health and well-being parameters via novel citizen science/crowdsourcing campaigns using low cost sensors; (b) Develop advanced computational algorithms to uncover hotspots and spatial correlations in the data and evaluate data-driven as well as discipline-inspired access and wellbeing hypotheses; (c) Using outcomes from (a) and (b) develop connected multi-infrastructure futures scenario models with new infrastructures through shared scenario visioning exercises, and evaluate policy learning and value of information; (d) Focus on education and workforce development for middle-high schoolers, graduate students and sustainability professionals.  Outcomes from this research will be useful for informing citizens and policymakers about smart infrastructure transition being planned in cities.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated a smart urban infrastructure systems framework (Figure 1) for advancing access and wellbeing in cities. With transformative new infrastructures (e.g., smart electricity grid, urban farms) on the horizon, this research provides new perspectives on how the deployment of these new infrastructures will shape wellbeing, health, and environmental sustainability outcomes in cities. The project advanced basic research in multiple disciplines including environmental and civil engineering, computer science, urban planning and public policy. It helped create a unique public database, established citizen science protocols, and advanced the science of smart sustainable urban systems with cities engaged in infrastructure planning. The project had a strong component of citizen science engagement with K-12 teachers and students, particularly in schools with underrepresented populations.

The research had four themes: (a) Develop the first comprehensive public database of over 100 social, ecological, health, and well-being parameters via crowdsourcing campaigns using low cost sensors; (b) Develop advanced computational algorithms to uncover hotspots and spatial correlations in the data and evaluate data-driven as well as discipline-inspired hypothesis related to access and wellbeing; (c) Use outcomes from (a) and (b) to develop future scenario models with new infrastructures through visioning exercises, and evaluate policy learning and value of information; (d) Promote education and workforce development for middle-high schoolers, graduate students and sustainability professionals. Outcomes from this research would be useful for informing citizens and policymakers about smart infrastructure transitions being planned in cities. Below we highlight three key outcomes.

We measured social equity in urban energy use and interventions using household-level data. Cities seek a nuanced understanding of intra-urban inequality in energy use, addressing both income and race, to inform more equitable investment in climate actions. For the study, the team partnered with two cities, St. Paul, Minnesota and Tallahassee, Florida, and utilities in those cities to collect empirical data covering ~200,000 households. The study found disparities in energy use intensity by income and race up to a factor of five times larger than previously understood in US cities. The study contributed to a fundamental understanding of social inequality in energy use by race and income and the nature of energy inequality at the scale of an urban area. It also demonstrated the applicability of the developed computational methods and metrics to cities. More details can be found in KangKang Tong et al., "Measuring social equity in urban energy use and interventions using fine-scale data," Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 118, no. 24 (2021): e2023554118.

We also studied bias in the rankings of US metropolitan regions based on segregation and income inequality. A 2015 report [1] had ranked the City of Tallahassee as the overall most economically segregated U.S. city among 350 metropolitan areas. Due to our focus on advancing equity in communities, we were approached by the Tallahassee Mayor and community leaders, who were concerned about social and policy impacts of the ranking on citizen satisfaction, allocation of public resources, etc. Our data science investigation found that the metropolitan area rankings were highly sensitive to choice of spatial unit (i.e., census block group vs. census tract). We developed a policy brief [2] and recommended that census-based rankings be evaluated for their sensitivity to the choice of spatial units (e.g., block, block group, and tract) and further analyzed using the finest available spatial scale. Technical details of the work can be found in Gupta et al., "Spatial Dimensions of Algorithmic Transparency: A Summary," 17th International Symposium on Spatial and Temporal Databases, pp. 116-125, 2021, ACM, https://doi.org/10.1145/3469830.3470898.

Furthermore, our team developed a web-based citizen science curriculum for assessing neighborhood infrastructure and well-being. We conducted multiple workshops and teacher training sessions to train minneapolis-st paul metropolitan middle school and high school teachers in the curriculum. The project engaged middle and high school students in neighborhood exploration, data gathering, online reporting/mapping and discourse on equity. At the end of the unit, students created 60 sustainability maps and 3 wellbeing datasets for analysis and social action.

 

[1] Richard Florida, Charlotta Mellander, Segregated City: The Geography of Economic Segregation in America's Metros, Martin Prosperity Institute, University of Toronto, 2015.

[2] Jayant Gupta, Tian Tang, & Shashi Shekhar. 2022. "National ranking is influenced by spatial units' choices: Comment on Richard Florida's 2015 Segregated City Report."
